Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Upright Laser Scanning Confocal Microscope to Advance Research and Education at the University of California, Merced
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Division of Materials Research (DMR) Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program, the University of California, Merced will acquire a state-of-the-art confocal laser-scanning microscope to serve as primary tool for biomaterials-based research and teaching. In a confocal microscope, a pinhole that rejects out-of-plane light allows imaging at a higher resolution than achievable through conventional optical microscopy. This optical sectioning allows reconstruction of three-dimensional images from optical slices. This microscope will dramatically augment the materials research facilities existing at UC Merced, specifically allowing research into: a) how do cells control the size of lipid domains in their membranes, b) how do we engineer synthetic cells, c) how do we design and characterize nano-assembled systems for energy and drug delivery, d) what are the effects of mechanical forces on the differentiation of stem cells, e) what are the effects of hydrophilic polymers on fluid transport in the rhizosphere, f) what are the short- and long-term dynamics of biofilms, and g) how do cooperation between fungi and bacteria occur in mixed biofilms. Research activities and research training on the microscope, of a large number of students from diverse backgrounds at UC Merced, a minority serving institution, benefits from this award. Furthermore, teacher training on the instrument will increase pre-college exposure to science and engineering in the surrounding communities.

The microscope will allow the PIs and senior personnel to conduct research requiring multi-modal imaging capabilities, such as a combination of high-resolution multichannel (up to six simultaneous channels) fluorescence microscopy, laser reflectance microscopy, bright-field microscopy, spectroscopic imaging, and high-signal-to-noise ratio imaging. The detectors feature linear scanning and superior signal-to-noise ratios thus allowing quantitative imaging of dim and lightly-labeled samples. The upright configuration allows reflective imaging of semiconductor chips, nanofilms, and nanoparticles on surfaces using long-working distance objectives. The upright configuration will also allow studies of phenomena where directionality is important, such as the formation of biofilm pellicles on air-water interfaces, and gravity and capillarity driven transport of liquids through the rhizosphere. This instrument will also allow students to receive hands on-training on the use and application of state-of-the-art microscopy techniques; particularly important for UC Merced, which has one of the nation's highest enrollment of first generation college students in a research university. The educational opportunities created by this instrument will further the university's commitment to diversity by investing institutional resources to recruit and retain students from underrepresented social and economic groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This major instrumentation award provided funds to purchase a pseudo-superresolution laser-scanning confocal microscope to advance research and teaching at the University of California, Merced.  At the time of the award, the grant allowed the purchase of a state-of-the-art instrument that was unavailable on campus and within a 100-mile radius of an underserved region of central California.

Throughout the duration of the grant, the advanced capabilities of the microscope have allowed significant research breakthroughs in projects that required high-resolution quantitative imaging.  Among a selection of contributions include:

The microscope has enabled the development of a new imaging-based method for quantifying the ‘molar yield’ of giant vesicles and measuring their size distribution. These giant vesicles are simplified mimics of biological cells. Prior to this work, there was no quantitative measure that allowed statistically rigorous comparison between different techniques or different conditions of assembly. New to the field data include 1) the distribution of sizes of vesicles is right-skewed and highly asymmetric, calling into question previous use of summary statistics such as a mean size or polydispersity index. These statistics assume a normally distributed population, 2) the introduction of the concept of a ‘molar yield’ of vesicles that allowed statistically rigorous quantitative comparison of different growth conditions, materials, and lipid types, 3) interrogation of the morphology of the vesiculating films. This work contributed to scalable methods to produce synthetic cells and drug delivery vehicles.

The microscope was also used to characterize optical properties of organo-metal halide perovskite (OMHP) thin films deposited using an electro-hydrodynamic (EHD) process. Data collected from the microscope was used to demonstrate significant scalability in OMHP based luminescent solar concentrators with optical efficiency rivaling the highest currently recorded value. Unlike other LSC systems, OMHP-based LSCs are solution processed and deposited easily on flexible substrates, allowing roll-to-roll processing, which reduces the price point greatly.

The microscope has been used to study the rhizosphere, the region of soil that surrounds individual plant roots. Although it is a small volume and narrow region compared to bulk soil, the rhizosphere regulates numerous processes that determine the physical structure, nutrient distribution, and biodiversity of soils. The essential mechanisms regulating hydraulic redistribution in the rhizosphere are still not clear. The reason for that is because we lack reliable and accurate methodologies to monitor the alteration of soil physical and chemical properties in the rhizosphere. Images from the microscope have been used to determine the spatial distribution of root exudates, a mixture of organic compounds released by the roots that plays essential functions in plant and soil health.

Images from the microscope have been used to study nutritional symbionts in sap-feeding insects. Possessing highly degenerate genomes, these symbionts require significant cellular and genetic support from their hosts. Experiments on aster leafhopper (Hemiptera: Macrosteles quadrilineatus) shows that the host differentially expresses thousands of genes in host specialized cells (bacteriocytes) to meet the functional needs of its two intracellular symbionts, Sulcia and Nasuia). For example, the host highly expresses genes in the bacteriocytes that likely complement gene losses in cellular information processing (CIP) and nutrition transport. To investigate if (i) host encoded genes are expressed in bacteria and bacteriocyte membrane, and (ii) hosts have evolved novel functional traits to support symbionts, immunofluorescence microscopy was used to localize gene products. Specifically, one HTG (frr) and one MT support gene (TSFM) involved in CIP systems, and one duplicated amino acid transporter (PAT-6) were selected. The cellular location of these gene products was verified with immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies that bind target genes.

The microscope has contributed to the training of the national STEM workforce on advanced scientific instrumentation. Over 85 people including faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students have been trained on the microscope during the grant period. Furthermore, over 30 high school students have been exposed or had hands on use of the microscope through outreach activities. The data collected by the students have contributed to publications, PhD dissertations, and scientific presentations. These products have allowed the students to participate in conferences and symposia locally, nationally, and internationally. These activities have furthered their professional development. The microscope has logged well-over 1000 user hours during the duration of the grant and will be available for continued use as a core instrument in a user-facility at UC Merced beyond the duration of the grant.
